Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: Having just moved in, they prepare a small cake to share with nearby neighbors when they happen to meet.
Expectation2: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation2: An emergency motion for a temporary restraining order has just been filed, requiring you to immediately review the documents and make a ruling within the hour.
Story:
I had just moved into the neighborhood, and with a small cake in hand, I was eager to introduce myself to the people next door. I wanted to be the kind of neighbor who was friendly and approachable, someone who made a good first impression. As I stepped into the hallway, cake balanced carefully, my phone buzzed with an urgent notification. An emergency motion for a temporary restraining order had just landed on my desk—one that demanded my immediate attention as a judge. The expectation was clear: I needed to review the case files thoroughly and make a ruling within the hour. 

Standing there, I could hear voices from the apartment next door, the perfect opportunity to say hello. But the weight of the case pressed on me. If I delayed, someone’s safety could be at risk. If I ignored my neighbors, I might come across as cold or unfriendly, undermining the sense of community I hoped to build. My heart pounded as I stood frozen, torn between the cake in my hand and the files waiting on my laptop, wrestling with the impossible demands of both roles.
